dc:description:
The relationship between SLC25A19 and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of June 8, 2020. The SLC25A19 gene encodes a mitochondrial thiamine pyrophosphate carrier, and mediates uptake of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) into mitochondria.

Pathogenic variants in SLC25A19 have been associated mainly with two phenotypes – Amish microcephaly and Leigh syndrome spectrum. 

The SLC25A19 gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Leigh syndrome spectrum in 2009 (PMID: 19798730). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included five variants identified in five cases in four publications (PMIDs: 19798730, 31506564, 31295743, 28856750). No segregation data were available. Loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by biochemical function and a model system (PMIDs: 18280798, 17035501). 

In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel June 8, 2020 (SOP Version 7).

evidence.dc:description: A western blot analysis was performed using whole cell homogenate from HepG2 cells. The results showed that the Q192H protein level is significantly (p < 0.01) lower than that of the WT hMTPPT. Computer models and protein modeling predict this mutation to be pathogenic.

evidence.rdfs:label: Bottega proband
evidence.detectionMethod: SNPs-array analysis was performed in our patient to study the presence of runs of homozygosity (ROHs) since an inbreeding mating was reported. Consistently, SNPs-array analysis revealed many areas of homozygosity, as in consanguinity. Eighteen ROHs turned out to be larger than 1 Mb. The SLC25A19 gene was within a 5.7 Mb ROH on chromosome 17 (chr17:71962659-77748961). The subsequent Sanger sequencing of SLC25A19 gene showed the homozygous mutation c.576G>C (Q192H) in exon 6.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The boy showed a history of neurological impairment due to an encephalopathy during fever. He had four acute events started during a fever episode when he was 1 year old, and characterized by tremors, hypotonia, gait difficulty, dysphagia, dysphonia, and alteration of consciousness. Now he is 18 years old and he presents a moderate cognitive delay, bilateral pes cavus with hammer toes (Fig. 1a), and atrophy of intraosseous muscles. Brain MRI shows multiple focal areas of signal alteration with caudate nucleus, putamen and cerebellum involvement, and slight symmetrical atrophy of the insula cortex (Fig. 1b, ​,c).c)

evidence.dc:description: Maximum points awarded as authors utilized a yeast complementation assay to demonstrate pathogenicity of the reported mutation.
Computer models predict this mutation to be damaging (Awarded 0.25 pts)

evidence.rdfs:label: Ortigoza-Escobar Pt 75
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Brain MRI demonstrated bilateral striatal necrosis with the following abnormal regions on neuroimaging: Caudate, Putamen, Globus pallidus, and Corticosubcortical. Patient had the following clinical findings: Encephalopathy, Tremor, Dystonia, Opistothonus, Paroxysmal Ataxia, vertigo, and  Dysphagia. Patient had elevated levels of lactate in the CSF at onset

evidence.dc:description: In silico prediction tool analysis (using PolyPhen-2) revealed mutation to be probably damaging.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gowda- Female Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
history of recurrent episodes of flaccid weakness followed by encephalopathy acutely after febrile illness;  Serum lactate level
was elevated (5.6 mmol/L; range: 0.5–2 mmol/L). MRI of the brain performed at 1 year and 4 months showed symmetrical hyperintensities in the bilateral basal ganglia and thalami (Images available for review).

evidence.dc:description:
In silico prediction tool analysis (using PolyPhen-2) revealed mutation to be probably
damaging.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gowda - Male Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: recurrent episodes of acute flaccid paralysis with encephalopathy following nonspecific febrile illness; Serum lactate level was high (8 mmol/L; range: 0.5–2 mmol/L). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain demonstrated patchy hyperintensities in the bilateral basal ganglia and thalami (Images available for review)

evidence.dc:description: The mouse model demonstrates biochemical abnormalities consistent with Leigh syndrome. Awarded 1.0 pts as per animal model scoring rubric.
This mouse model recapitulates reduced PDH activity and elevated lactate, biochemical abnormalities, that have been seen in humans with Leigh syndrome.
evidence.rdfs:label: SLC25A19 knock out mouse

evidence.dc:description: The SLC25A19 encoded protein shares a biochemical relationship or function with 2-5 gene products whose dysfunction is known to cause Leigh syndrome (Awarded 1 pt)

SLC25A19 is a mitochondrial transporter mediating uptake of thiamine pyrophosphate (ThPP) into mitochondria. According to Leigh map, two other proteins involved in thiamine transport or processing have been implicated in causing Leigh Syndrome (SLC19A3 and TPK1) (Rahman 2017 PMID: 27977873). Therefore, the function of SLC25A19 is shared with two other known genes in the disease of interest.
evidence.rdfs:label: Thiamine Transport
